STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
August 18, 2020
Barbara LaRue
Kalamazoo County DHHS
322 Stockbridge
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
RE: License #: CP390201215
Kalamazoo County DHHS
322 Stockbridge
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
Dear Ms. LaRue:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
August 17, 2020. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It
should be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of
the ISEP and policy. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Repeat violations require an explanation on why the previous corrective
action plan was unsuccessful.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (616) 552-3662.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Jessica VandenHeuvel, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
Suite 200
121 Franklin Street SE
Grand Rapids, MI 49507
(616) 204-6992
enclosure
Kathy Miller, BSC Director
2

MICHIGAN DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING
RENEWAL INSPECTION REPORT
I. IDENTIFYING INFORMATION
License #: CP390201215
Licensee Name: Michigan Department of Health and Human
Services
Licensee Address: 235 South Grand Avenue
Lansing, MI 48902
Licensee Telephone #: (517) 373-3768
Administrator/Licensee Designee: Barbara LaRue, Administrator
Jooyeun Chang, Designee
Name of Facility: Kalamazoo County DHHS
Facility Address: 322 Stockbridge
Kalamazoo, MI 49001
Facility Telephone #: (269) 337-5000
Original Issuance Date: 09/10/1993
Service Types: PLACE CHILDREN FOR ADOPTION
CERTIFY FOSTER HOMES FOR LICENSE
SUPERVISE INDEPENDENT LIVING
PLACE CHILDREN IN FOSTER HOME
EVALUATE APPLICANTS FOR ADOPTION
1

Date of On-site Inspection(s): 08/10/2020

Reviewed

3

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules
except for the following:
R 400.12311 Foster parent/agency agreement
(3) An agency shall document review of the foster
parent/agency agreement with the foster family at least annually
and, when needed, develop a new agreement.
One of six foster home files reviewed lacked an annual foster parent/agency
agreement as required.
R 400.12325 License recommendation.
(3) Except for an original license, an agency shall recommend to
the department the issuance of a regular license or the
continuation of an active license only when all rules are in
compliance or both of the following conditions exist:
(b) A written corrective action plan has been developed. The
plan shall be in compliance with all of the following
requirements:
(iii) Be signed and dated by the foster parent and the
agency.
One of three foster home files reviewed where a corrective action plan was required
lacked the foster parent’s signature on the plan as required.
R 400.12326 Borrowed home.
(1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
agency or tribe, the agency shall have a record containing all of
the following documents:
(c) A copy of the initial evaluation with written endorsement
by the borrowing agency that the evaluation is acceptable.
One of three borrowed bed files reviewed was missing written endorsement of the of
initial evaluation after placement of the child in the foster home.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(1) An agency shall do all of the following when anyone in the
agency receives information that relates to possible
noncompliance with any foster home rule:
4

(b) Initiate a special evaluation of the foster home as soon as
is indicated, based on the information received, but not later
than 7 calendar days after receipt of the information.
In one of six foster home files reviewed, a complaint was made on the foster home
but there was no special investigation initiated to address the complaint.
R 400.12327 Special evaluation.
(5) Within 15 days of the conclusion of the evaluation, an
agency shall complete a written report that includes all of the
following information:
(f) Conclusions regarding licensing rules compliance or
noncompliance based on the findings of fact.
One of six special investigations documented within the evaluation the family locked
a youth in their bedroom and had a child over the age of three sleeping in the parent
bedroom. However, the agency found the foster home in compliances with the rules
which was not consistent with the findings of fact presented within the report.
R 400.12405 Change of placement.
(3) The agency shall document all of the following in the child’s
record before a change of placement occurs:
(a) Reason for the change in placement.
(b) If the child is not returned to the parent then the
reason why return is not possible.
(c) If the child is not reunited with siblings or placed with a
relative, then the reason why those placements are not
possible.
(d) Consideration of the factors identified in R
400.12404(4).
(e) Replacement preparation, regardless of the child’s
age, appropriate to the child’s capacity to understand,
which includes an explanation to all relevant parties as to
why the change is necessary.
(f) Notification to the parents, referral source, lawyer
guardian ad litem, and courts when applicable, of the
change in placement.
(g) Information about the child was shared with the new
placement, consistent with the requirements of R
400.12417.
(h) The child’s new location and address.
(i) That the current foster parent was notified in writing of
the following information:
(i) Not less than 14 calendar days in advance, of
the change, except when prior notification would
5

jeopardize the child’s care or safety. If prior notice
is not provided, then the agency shall notify the
foster parent, at the time of the change, why prior
notice was not given.
(ii) Of the current foster parent’s rights concerning
the change in placement.
(j) Supervisory approval before the change.
Two of six foster care youth files reviewed lacked completion of the action summary
timely that would have captured the information required in subsections (a) through
(g).
One of three foster care youth files reviewed lacked notification to the foster parent
in writing of the change of placement as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection dated 8/27/19, CAP approval date 9/13/19
Renewal Inspection dated 9/21/18, CAP approval date 10/2/18
R 400.12417 Foster parent information.
(1) An agency shall provide a foster parent with all of the
following information before the placement or replacement of a
child:
(a) Child's name.
(b) Child’s date of birth.
(c) Available known information about the child’s health.
(d) Any known history of abuse or neglect of the child.
(e) All known emotional and psychological factors relating
to the care of the child.
(f) All known behavioral problems of the child.
(g) Circumstances necessitating placement or
replacement of the child.
(h) Any other known information to enable the foster
parent to provide a stable, safe, and healthy environment
for the foster child and the foster family, including
information about siblings who do not reside in the foster
home.
(i) Name of assigned social service worker.
6

Two of six foster care youth files reviewed, lacked documentation the caregiver was
provided with the information required in subsections (a) through (i) which would
have been captured on the Initial Placement Outline.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection dated 9/21/18, CAP approval date 10/2/18
R 400.12418 Development of service plans.
(2) An agency shall complete written service plans for each child
and parent or parents, as follows:
(a) Within 30 calendar days from removal from the home.
(b) Within 120 calendar days after the initial removal and at
least once every 90 calendar days thereafter.
Two of three foster care youth files reviewed requiring an initial service plan be
completed, was late by 6 and 11 days, respectively.
One of six foster care youth files reviewed requiring an updated service plan be
completed was late. In the one file two updated service plans were late by 8 and 28
days, respectively.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection dated 8/27/19, CAP approval date 9/13/19
Renewal Inspection dated 9/21/18, CAP approval date 10/2/18
PA 116 Investigation and examination of conditions, books,
722.120(2) records, and reports; visits regarding health or fire
protection; records; reports; forms; confidentiality;
disclosure of information; availability of confidential
records.
(2) A licensee shall keep the records the department prescribes
regarding each child in its control and care and shall report to
the department, when requested, the facts the department
requires with reference to the children upon forms furnished by
the department. Except as otherwise provided in this
subsection, records regarding children and facts compiled about
children and their parents and relatives are confidential and
disclosure of this information shall be properly safeguarded by
the child care organization, the department, and any other entity
in possession of the information. Records that re confidential
under this section are available to both of the following:
(a) A standing select committee or appropriations
subcommittee of either house of the legislature having
jurisdiction over protective services matters for children,
7

pursuant to section 7 of the child protection law, 1975 PA
238, MCL 722.627.
(b) The children’s ombudsman established in section 3 of the
children’s ombudsman act 1994 PA 204, MCL 722.923.
In one foster home file reviewed involving Child Protective Services, the agency
identified Child Protective Service involvement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection dated 8/27/19, CAP approval date 9/13/19
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that there are
additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility is in
compliance will all additional ISEP requirements except for the following:
ISEP 6.19 Assessments and Service Plans, Content
(c) Service plans shall be signed by the caseworker, the
caseworker’s supervisor, the parent(s), and the child(ren), if of
age to participate. IF the parent(s) or child(ren) or both are not
available or decline to sign the plan, the service plan shall
include an explanation of the steps taken to involve them and
shall identify any follow-up action s to be taken to secure their
participation in services.
Seven of seven open foster care case files reviewed lacked the required signatures
on the parent agency agreement.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection dated 8/27/19, CAP approval date 9/13/19
Renewal Inspection dated 9/21/18, CAP approval date 10/2/18- ISEP 6.33
ISEP 6.16 Supervisory Oversight
Supervisors shall meet a least monthly with each assigned
worker to review the status of progress of each case on the
worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall review and approve each
service plan. The plan can be approved only after the supervisor
has a face-to-face meeting with the worker, which can be the
monthly meeting.
Two of eight open foster care case files reviewed lacked documentation of monthly
supervision as required.
ISEP 6.21 Visits, Worker-Child
(a)Each child in foster care shall be visited by a caseworker at
least two time per month during the child’s first two months of
placement in an initial or new placement, and at least one time
8

per month thereafter. At least one visit each month shall take
place at the child’s placement location and shall include a
private meeting between the child and the caseworker.
One of eight open foster care case files reviewed lacked documentation of monthly
visits between the worker and child in subsequent months as required.
ISEP 6.22 Visits, Worker-Parent
(a)For each child in foster care with a permanency goal of
reunification, the child’s caseworker shall have face-to-face
contacts with the child’s parent(s) as follows:
(1) for the first month the child is in care, two face-to-face
contact with each parent, at least one of which must occur in the
parent’s place of residence.
(2) for each subsequent month, at least one face-to-face contact
with each parent and phone contact as needed, with at least on
contact in each three-month period occurring in the parent’s
place of residence.
Four of seven open foster care case files reviewed with a goal of reunification lacked
documentation of monthly contact with the parent as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection dated 8/27/19, CAP approval date 9/13/19
Renewal Inspection dated 9/21/18, CAP approval date 10/2/18
ISEP 6.24 Visits, Between Siblings
(a) DHHS shall ensure that children in foster care who have
siblings in custody with whom they are not placed shall have
at least monthly visits with their siblings who are placed
elsewhere in DHHS foster care custody. Exceptions to this
requirement are cases in which:
(1) the visit may be harmful to one or more of the siblings;
(2) the sibling is placed out of state in compliance with the
Interstate Compact on Placement of Children;
(3) the distance between the children's placements is more
than 50 miles and the child is placed with a relative; or
(4) one of the siblings is above the age of 16 and refuses
such visits.
(b) All exceptions and all reasonable steps taken to assure that
visits take place shall be documented in the case file.
9

Three of three open foster care files reviewed where siblings were not placed
together, the monthly sibling visits were not documented to occur each month as
required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection dated 8/27/19, CAP approval date 9/13/19
Renewal Inspection dated 9/21/18, CAP approval date 10/2/18
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS policy violation. Please note that there
are additional DHS Policy requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance will all additional DHS Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 722-06H Caseworker Contacts
Caseworker contacts with Caregiver(s)
If there are two caregivers, such as a primary and secondary
caregiver, the caseworker must have a face-to-face contact with
the secondary caregiver in the home at least once each quarter.
One of five foster care files reviewed lacked documentation the secondary caregiver
was seen in the home at least once each quarter as required.
FOM 722-08C Foster Care Parent Agency Treatment Plan & Service
Agreement
Signatures
When completed, obtain all signatures as appropriate, including
those of parent(s)/guardian(s), foster care worker, supervisor,
foster parent, caregiver, any youth age 14 and older and in the
case of placement agency foster care cases, the local DHS
office designee.
Four of five open foster care youth files reviewed lacked the required caregiver
signatures timely, which would indicate their involvement in the plan development.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Renewal Inspection dated 9/21/18, CAP approval date 10/2/18
FOM 722-06B Family Team Meetings
Types and Timeframes
FTMs must occur within the required time frames as outlined in
the following tables:
10

Case Plan Development/ Reassessment
Initial Case Plan (ISP) - within 30 calendar days before the case
plan due date.
Note: This FTM may be combined with the CPS Case Opening
(ISP) FTM.
Updated Case Plan (USP) - within 30 calendar days before the
case plan due date.
Permanent Ward Service Plan (PWSP) - within 30 calendar days
before the case plan due date.
In five of eight open foster care youth files reviewed, the Case Plan Development/
Reassessment Family Team Meeting was not completed as required.
In two of eight open foster care youth files reviewed, the activity report (DHS 1105)
was not uploaded into MiSACWIS as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection dated 8/27/19, CAP approval date 9/13/19
Renewal Inspection dated 9/21/18, CAP approval date 10/2/18
FOM 722-3 Placement Selection and Standards
Residential Placement Exception Request
11

Two of two open foster youth files reviewed requiring a residential placement
exception request was not completed as required.
One of three open foster youth files reviewed where siblings were split lacked a
sibling split placement exception request.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection dated 8/27/19, CAP approval date 9/13/19
Renewal Inspection dated 9/21/18, CAP approval date 10/2/18
FOM 722-09 Supervisory Approval - USP
Prior to finalizing, the USP along with the required assessments
(FANS, CANS, etc.) must be reviewed and approved by the
foster care supervisor only after a face-to-face meeting with the
foster care worker.
Case service plan approval process requires the foster care
supervisor to:
• Review and approve the USP within 14 calendar days of the
report date.
Three of eight foster care youth files reviewed the supervisor did not approve a case
service plan within 14 days as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection dated 8/27/19, CAP approval date 9/13/19
Renewal Inspection dated 9/21/18, CAP approval date 10/2/18
FOM 801 Health Services for Children in Foster Care
Medical Passport requirements
Six of eight open case files reviewed lacked the medical passport being completed
as required.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Interim Inspection dated 8/27/19, CAP approval date 9/13/19
Renewal Inspection dated 9/21/18, CAP approval date 10/2/18
FOM 722-3B Relative Engagement and Placement
Notification Process: Caseworkers must pursue the identification
and notification of relatives and document the initial and ongoing
efforts in the investigation report and each case service plan.
Two of eight open case files reviewed lacked documentation of the agency’s efforts
to pursue the identification of relatives as required.
12

IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 The agency was informed they need to submit a change application with their
new address so that their license is correct and the Division of Child Welfare
Licensing will need to complete an addendum to their original study due to the
agency moving locations at the end of the month.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not in need of consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
AND
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period in response to the 2019 Interim Inspection
Report.
A virtual tour occurred of the agency. They are currently preparing to move to a new
location at the end of the month. CHRI storage was reviewed and found to be in
compliance and a cross shredder was available for destruction. A variety of staff
were interviewed. Staff reported support from management especially with the
change in mobile work as a result from the pandemic. Although staff also reported
frustration with Kalamazoo specific requirements that are beyond what is expected
by rules and policy.
VII. DCWL FIELD ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no safety alerts.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or policy. Upon receipt of
13

an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility will be
issued a renewal of their regular license.
August 17, 2020
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
August 18, 2020
________________________________________
Claudia Triestram Date
Area Manager
14
